quiz.title: Unit 6: Market Structures (Quiz 18)
quiz.subtitle: 6.6 Monopoly: Single Seller Markets (20 Questions)
quiz.subject: Economics
quiz.topic: Monopoly Characteristics, Barriers to Entry, Profit Maximization, Inefficiency

questions.question: The defining characteristic of a monopoly is:
options: A single seller with no close substitutes
A few large firms dominating the market
questions.explanation: A monopoly exists when there is only one seller of a product with no close substitutes, giving the firm significant market power.

questions.question: For a monopolist, the relationship between price and marginal revenue is:
questions.explanation: Because monopolists face downward-sloping demand curves, to sell more units they must lower price on all units, making marginal revenue less than price.

questions.question: A monopolist maximizes profit by producing where:
questions.explanation: Like all profit-maximizing firms, monopolists produce where marginal revenue equals marginal cost, but they then charge the highest price the market will bear for that quantity.

questions.question: At the profit-maximizing output for a monopolist:
questions.explanation: Since $MR < P$ and the firm produces where $MR = MC$, it follows that at the optimal output, $P > MC$.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a barrier to entry that can create monopolies?
questions.explanation: Perfect information is characteristic of competitive markets, not monopolies. Barriers to entry include economies of scale, legal protection, and resource control.

questions.question: A natural monopoly exists when:
options: One firm can supply the entire market at lower cost than multiple firms
There are no close substitutes for the product
questions.explanation: A natural monopoly occurs when economies of scale are so extensive that one firm can supply the entire market at a lower average cost than could multiple firms.

questions.question: Compared to perfect competition, a monopoly typically produces:
options: More output at a lower price
Less output at a higher price
The same output at the same price
More output at a higher price
questions.explanation: Monopolists restrict output and charge higher prices than would prevail under perfect competition to maximize their profits.

questions.question: The deadweight loss in monopoly results from:
options: The transfer of consumer surplus to producer surplus
The reduction in total economic surplus compared to perfect competition
questions.explanation: Deadweight loss represents the reduction in total economic surplus (consumer + producer surplus) that occurs because the monopoly produces less than the socially optimal quantity.

questions.question: A monopolist will never operate in the:
options: Elastic portion of the demand curve
Inelastic portion of the demand curve
Unit elastic portion of the demand curve
questions.explanation: A profit-maximizing monopolist will always produce where demand is elastic ($|E_d| > 1$) because in the inelastic region, marginal revenue is negative.

questions.question: The relationship between a monopolist's marginal revenue and price elasticity of demand is:
questions.explanation: This formula shows that $MR = P$ when $|E_d| = \infty$ (perfect competition), and $MR < P$ when demand is less than perfectly elastic.

questions.question: If a monopolist is earning economic profits in the short run, in the long run:
options: New firms will enter and compete away the profits
The monopolist will continue earning economic profits
The government will force price reductions
The monopolist will voluntarily lower prices
questions.explanation: Due to barriers to entry, monopolists can maintain economic profits in the long run, unlike perfectly competitive firms.

questions.question: Price discrimination occurs when a firm:
options: Charges different prices to different customers for the same product
Charges the same price to all customers
Lowers prices to drive out competitors
Sets prices equal to marginal cost
questions.explanation: Price discrimination involves charging different prices to different consumers for the same product based on their willingness to pay.

questions.question: For perfect price discrimination to be possible, the monopolist must:
options: Have identical costs for all units
Operate in the inelastic portion of demand
questions.explanation: To practice perfect price discrimination, the monopolist must be able to prevent arbitrage (resale) among customers and identify each customer's willingness to pay.

questions.question: Under perfect price discrimination, consumer surplus is:
options: The same as under single-price monopoly
questions.explanation: With perfect price discrimination, the monopolist captures all consumer surplus, charging each consumer exactly their maximum willingness to pay.

questions.question: The main source of inefficiency in monopoly is that:
questions.explanation: The fundamental inefficiency is that $P > MC$, indicating that the value to consumers exceeds the cost of production, leading to underproduction and deadweight loss.

questions.question: A monopolist's supply curve:
options: Is the portion of MC above AVC
Is the same as the demand curve
questions.explanation: Unlike perfect competition, a monopolist does not have a well-defined supply curve because there's no unique relationship between price and quantity supplied.

questions.question: If a monopolist faces a linear demand curve, the marginal revenue curve:
options: Has the same intercept and twice the slope
Has the same slope and half the intercept
Is identical to the demand curve
Is horizontal at the market price
questions.explanation: For a linear demand curve $P = a - bQ$, the marginal revenue curve is $MR = a - 2bQ$ - same vertical intercept but twice the slope.

questions.question: Regulation of natural monopolies often involves setting price equal to:
questions.explanation: Regulators often use average cost pricing for natural monopolies, allowing them to cover all costs including normal profit but not earn economic profit.

questions.question: The Lerner Index measures:
questions.explanation: The Lerner Index $L = \frac{P - MC}{P}$ measures monopoly power, ranging from 0 (perfect competition) to 1 (maximum monopoly power).

questions.question: Compared to perfect competition, monopoly results in:
options: Higher consumer surplus and lower producer surplus
Lower consumer surplus and higher producer surplus
Higher both consumer and producer surplus
Lower both consumer and producer surplus
questions.explanation: Monopoly transfers some consumer surplus to producer surplus (through higher prices) and creates deadweight loss, reducing total economic surplus.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You thoroughly understand monopoly characteristics, profit maximization, and the sources of market inefficiency.
scoreMessages.70: Good work! You understand the basics but review the MR-MC rule for monopolists, barriers to entry, and the welfare implications.
scoreMessages.50: A fair start. Focus on: why $MR < P$ for monopolists, how they maximize profit, and the comparison with perfect competition.
scoreMessages.0: Keep practicing! Remember that monopolists are single sellers who maximize profit where $MR = MC$ but charge $P > MC$, creating deadweight loss.
